text:
Even with all the time given up to me
now by lockdown

there still isn't enough time. it takes
for ever... !
And it's a good job i'm semi-retired from

being a part ofthe School of Computer
Science at [University of] Nottingham because
honestly, as a regular employee,  I could not justify
the hours i've spent on my latest ultra-fascinating project.

I refer you, my dear Watson, to the
strange case

of Dennis Ritchie's missing thesis.
We all know who Dennis is. UNIX was

invented by Ken and Dennis:  Ken Thompson 
and Dennis Ritchie.

If you want to simplify things
Ken was sort of in charge of UNIX the

operating system. [But] anything to do 
with creating C language

facilities and C compilers
because, remember, UNIX was one of the

very first operating systems
to be written in a specially invented

high-level language called
C. And Dennis was an absolute whiz

with the C compiler, And it needed both
of them to do this,
So, again, many of you will know Dennis because

one of the best-selling computer
programming textbooks of all time
is "The C Programming Language" by Dennis Ritchie
and our good Computerphile colleague and friend

Brian Kernighan. There's some big gaps in
our knowledge about

Dennis and I should remind you, I think,
sadly, he died in 2010 [Correction: October 2011]

and he has been must much missed in
the 10 years or so since that.

But recently the Computer History Museum (CHM)
in the USA

came up with a story which just amazed
everybody. People who knew him said:

"Yeah! Yeah! he went to Harvard 
and we think he did an

Applied Mathematics degree.
So of course he was Dr

Ritchie wasn't he? He did a PhD ? 
Well the answer is he

studied for a PhD
but it never properly got submitted.

The Examination Panel was appointed; they
never met.
And the CHM story, basically, says "We don't totally

feel happy about this story... " 
The cover story is that
there was a standoff and that there was a need
to submit bound library copies of his thesis.

Dennis objected to having to pay
to have this done. He thought he

made enough sacrifices already
(presumably) in keeping himself alive

while he did his PhD thesis.
It's worth saying his PhD was a very

theoretical one. In coming out of the Maths 
department,

perhaps not too surprising. But he
regarded his thesis as something to be
got out of the way. But he was far more
interested in playing Space Wars and writing

real (prototype) C programs that were useful to 
help out Ken

his new-found friend, you see. I know
you'll all say: "You [seem to] know everybody,

Don't name-drop !" [But], yes, i have to confess 
I did meet Dennis

Ritchie once. It was in 1986.
Brian had been over to see me in the
early 80s. I paid a return visit to Bell Labs

i had a very enjoyable lunch: Dennis
Ken, Brian and me, in which Ken regaled

us with his story
about [how], if you were a qualified pilot

you could get to fly a MIG in Russia, if you 
played your cards right. They [in Russia] were so
short of foreign currency, foreign exchange, at

that time. [So]  any gimmick that brought in
tons of dollars, you see, was

absolutely fine.  So, yes, i did meet Dennis
just that once

and ...  totally charming guy. It takes one 
to spot one [but] he was a computer scientist!
And so was Ken. They were so similar to each other but

so different, you know. 
They had this wicked way of answering

exactly what you'd asked
not what you wish you'd asked.

Ken didn't get a PhD but he did enroll 
for a Masters [degree], Ii think,
at Berkeley and got that.  So he was known about.

But everybody just assumed that Dennis
must have got his PhD from Harvard
There were no hitches? Turns out there were!

And Bell Labs were not pleased
to find that this person they'd
appointed, who they knew was good. They chased
after him as solidly as they chased after Ken.
I think they were tipped off how good he was but

to find suddenly ... I think it was somebody from
Bell Labs who wrote to Harvard and said:

"What is going on ?"
When will Mr Ritchie get his PhD.

And they got back the frostiest reply you will
ever see,

effectively saying: "We have no plans - nor
are we likely to have any plans -

to give Mr Ritchie a PhD ... " 
He had upset somebody mightily

and neither I, nor Brian nor his 
[Dennis's] brother Bill,

still we don't know the true story. 
Maybe we never will.

1967 was a long time ago, even for me.
Just think of that - I was only 23 !
It's like back in the Jurassic, you know.

And just to put things absolutely clear,
What would have been available to Dennis

for his output medium for his thesis?
Really something like a clattery

Model 37 Teletype were becoming available
[at that time].
They had a fixed character set;  you couldn't

sort of extend it in any way. But they were very 
good [for medium quality]. i mean, you could have a

Teletype plugged in [to your computer] 
They were used in Stock Exchanges

so they were a common currency [computer peripheral].
So, you could plug a Teletype into your computer.
>> Sean: So, this thesis does exist then - it did exist?
>> DFB: It did exist,  you see. His sister Lynn, who I think died
two or three years ago, was very fond of her brother and

looked after him carefully.
She had a copy of his finally submitted thesis.
One of his fellow PhD students also from Harvard,

Albert Meyer, quite a name in theoretical
computer science but of course,
again now, he'll have retired. He had one and

the other one, if you like, was Dennis's
own working copy.

which eventually got submitted - or was
about to be submitted. Normally, at this

period, what you would do was handwrite
all your great thoughts and hand it to a

[technically trained] typist.
The idea of being able to do it on a

computer and with computer assistance
was at its very very infancy.

We have a copy here of what it was like.
It could have been submitted [but] it didn't get
submitted. But Dennis decided, quite rightly, that

a Teletype terminal wasn't powerful
enough because it didn't have enough
characters. So if you're going to either hand type it,
or typeset it from a peripheral stuck into
a computer, what were your options? Well, your options
were either an ultra-expensive, very early,

photo-typesetter [with] 
font characters as photos on a

film strip.
So, your a - z were 26 different little

bits of film,
probably wrapped around a drum that you

could illuminate from behind.
Massively, massively, expensive. Even Bell

Labs hadn't invested in one of those at
the time.

Although a few years later they did so.
If you come back from those
rarified heights you could type it by hand

and if it was an old-fashioned
typewriter you had special characters on
little things that look like nail-varnish sticks [Typits]
that you put into the throat of the typewriter
and you hit any key. And it was like a sort of

relayed impact. That alpha character [say] was
actually

typed [as]  'i' or something, any character would do
And it hit
the back of this special gadget and you got,

at the right place, the letter alpha.
But going beyond that -- because that was a

pain --  IBM came up with the idea of a 
golf-ball typewriter.

[IBM video of Selectric in action]
"This is the best thing that's happened
to typing since electricity".

"The IBM Slectric typewriter." They are
miraculous things,

unbelievable. What they did was that,
instead of having

26 different dipsticks [Typits] for weird
characters

they would put put them on, let's say, a
Greek characters golf-ball

[So] for special purposes you take out your
regular golfball, you plug in a Greek

characters one.
When you look at the way that they

[IBM] embedded those metal characters 
onto the surface of a sphere,
in such a way that if the sphere rocked

ever so slightly, 
another row of characters became
as it were 'normal' to the paper and could be hit.

>> Sean: With a typewriter you can have little
arms with a metal

kind of thing that gets .... 
>> DFB: at the end and
they all end up in the
neck, or the throat, or whatever it's called and

on a conventional typewriter you move
the sheet around [to place the characters]

With a Selectric you only move the sheet
for line feeds forward and back.
You didn't move the sheet for horizontal motion(s).
This unbelievable cradle with a golf ball in it,

going seemingly at the speed of sound
was leaping all over, left and right,

putting in characters.
It is an electro-mechanical marvel of the

first order.
And it did not come cheap! It cost as much as ...

well the story at the time was -- those of
you on the far side of the Atlantic can

translate this better than me --
it cost as much as a Buick. Now a Buick
is not an utterly luxurious saloon, I don't think,
But it's not cheap!  And it certainly wasn't cheap

in those days, So it [a Selectric 2741 peripheral]
cost as much as a medium-sized saloon car,

just for this output device! And Dennis
having been taken on by

Bell Labs as the 'bright new lad',
actually conned them into letting him
have an online version of one of these devices

it's called a 2741 and [it also had] a 
dedicated [telephone] line that
had a monthly rental at eye-watering prices.

just so that, as well as working for Bell
Labs in his new job,

he could also have a golf-ball machine down 
there [in the basement of the Ritchie family house]

where he did experiments on how to typeset 
his thesis properly.

And brother Bill (We'll point to his Web site -- 
https://dmrthesis.net) aged nine [Correction: twelve] 
years old, at the time
was just in awe of Dennis sitting in their basement

(in the Ritchie family house).
Dennis rented the basement, just

swapping golf balls and messing about
with this thing [which was] in

one corner of the basement, from what I
understand.

But, even so, how did he, in the end,
manage 180 pages of thesis
with changes of characters all over the place?

>> Sean: Because we're talking about [essentially]
typesetting equations here aren't we?
>> DFB: yes, I'd probably better turn our attention

to this one I think [points at equation on hard-copy printout]
which is pretty horrifying. I mean when
you look at it there are the obvious alphabetic

characters there.
But at the moment, inked in, is

a Greek 'rho', or is it a 'p' symbol
in Dennis's own handwriting. And just the

sheer density of this stuff, one [equation] 
on top of another.
A funny thing there which is a 'monus' operator.
So, this is horrifying to contemplate
is: "How many golf-ball changes would you need

to typeset that page?"  Because what you've
got to do is do all the easy stuff - and

there isn't much easy stuff here - set it 
[the golfball carriage] back, in a

sense, to a 'home' position and put the paper 
back in again.

In other words, if it's on tractor feed,
make sure you get back to exactly the

right start position, 
then go through it [the document] waving the golf ball
around on its carriage and then deciding:

"Ah!, I'm needed there. Let's type one
character there." So, you might end up

having to do multi-pass processing on
just about every page, depending on complexity.
Now some of you may remember we did
- actually you may not even recognize it

as a comparable exercise. About 6 or 7 years 
ago we did [on 'Computerphile] a thing about the
Vacation Memo. It was a 13-page [Bell Labs] memo

of the fights they [Bell Labs] had had with 
Mergenthaler, and with the [202 typesetter] hardware,

to get everything working. But they
succeeded in the end. We effectively wanted
to do, for Dennis's thesis, what we did in

rescuing the Vacation Memo.
The trouble is it's not only ten times
longer, is this thesis,  it's also easily ten

times harder to do,
because his material is so complex.

[For] the stuff on the 202 we were rescued by
the fact that

fonts carried on beyond the 202 [into laser-printers] 
[and] into the great new world of Adobe Type 1 [fonts],

Truetype fonts, Open Type fonts for
those of you into these things.

There are standards.
You can miss out all the [electro-mechanical] 
stuff in the

middle take a flying leap into the world of fonts 
And things become

easier fortunately.
How do we make our flying leap here?

Here is a font, if you
care to call it that, which basically

exists on a golf-ball on a typewrite.r
Not a traditional conveyance mechanism
for what a typographer might call a 'real font'.
Nevertheless, our good friend Chuck Bigelow,
typographer and giant of the Lucida typeface family,
when advising us said: "i'll have a look around and see
if somebody has seen fit to turn the Selectric font

into what we would call a 'proper font' "
And he found for us

from the Bitstream foundry, a font which
I think is called Pica 10 and it's

pretty darn close to what a standard
Selectric golf-ball has got.

But unfortunately nobody did the exotic
symbols [e.g. Script, Greek, Math - all
at fixed pitch].

And the thing about the main running
text is that because it came off a

typewriter [device] it's what's called 'fixed pitch'. 
Maybe a

lot of you don't realize this, but
if you have a fixed-pitch typewriter

have you ever noticed that the problem 
is that the letter 'i' [for example]

looks very lonely because there has to be a
lot of space on either side of it
The fixed pitch of these characters is 602

one thousandth of an inch  
[Correction: thousandths of an em]
- OK for ordinary alphabets.

But when you get extended characters
like a [lower case] Greek alpha,
which has got a floppy head and a floppy tail

they don't look very good at fixed pitch.
[Ideally] you have to redesign them but they look
all constrained and not their usual florid self.

There have been no *fixed pitch* redrawings 
as far as we can find

[for creating] a typewriter-compatible font 
of the Greek Symbol golf-ball [say].

It's a minority interest. So I've
had to do my best in

rescuing Dennis's thesis; work is
ongoing it'll take quite some time yet,

to say: "Well we'll have to use
a variable pitched typewriter-like

font for the exotic symbols." 
So, for example,

the [lower case] alpha symbol in Greek
requires a variable pitch of 890

thousdandths [of an em] not 602.
And if you start to say: "Come on Brailsford stop

being lazy! Just take the variable
pitched font

and using your innate [type-design] skills
squash it down into being a fixed

pitch version [602/1000] of it.
It's hard!  If you don't believe me read

my semi-rant back in the Vacation Memo
paper it took me something like
120 - 150 hours to create a font called PrintOut and
the results look rubbish unless you have artistic

[type design] innate capability. Which i don't" 
It means that my lines on the [DMR thesis] rebuild

are sometimes a bit longer than Dennis's
because i'm having to use

quite a few variable-pitch characters
that are inevitably - they look more elegant -
but they're longer [i.e. wider] than they would be in

a fixed-pitch version. So under my left finger
[points at original thesis page]  is the
stuff that Dennis left - his display equations.

Swapping over quickly here [and] using the bit
stream Pica 10 font

is my attempted rebuild of the same
material. I'm still working on it but can
you see the 'pi' symbol there - it looks better

There's all sorts of things. For those of
you saying: "Well how are you producing it?"

I've allowed myself
the anachronism of going five years

later in Bell Labs history.
Anybody who's into ancient UNIX would

say that [this material] was yelling out 
for 'eqn' and 'troff'

so  why didn't Dennis use them? 
They hadn't [yet] been invented !

His thesis was in [late] 1967. 
Eqn and troff weren't there until 1972

And [this material] it's got superscript and 
superscript positions.

And you must respect those because those
affect the meaning

of the equations. He was five years ahead
of his time and Lord

knows how he did it but in following him
- may we be forgiven - we're giving

ourselves five years
benefit and comforting ourselves that
had Dennis done his thesis five years later, he

would [almost certainly] have used these tools.
So we have used 'eqn' to set these
equations feeding into the device independent

[ditroff] version of 'troff'
because stylistically and date-wise

they are earlier than things like TEX 
and LATEX, by quite a bit.
So, this seemed to us to be the best
reproduction compromise.
